content.raw:
Can you clarify a few things for me so I know the expected behaviour? And maybe you can update the documentation to make it clearer according to the answers...

1. Static means the camera position is fixed. Would it then just follow the model by changing its orientation?

1. Is xyz only used if static is true, and distance only used if static is set to false?

1. What happens if both relative and static are true? The initial position is expressed in the model frame but when the model moves the camera stays attached to the world (and the distance between camera and model changes)?
content.html:
Can you clarify a few things for me so I know the expected behaviour? And maybe you can update the documentation to make it clearer according to the answers...

  1. Static means the camera position is fixed. Would it then just follow the model by changing its orientation?

  2. Is xyz only used if static is true, and distance only used if static is set to false?

  3. What happens if both relative and static are true? The initial position is expressed in the model frame but when the model moves the camera stays attached to the world (and the distance between camera and model changes)?

content.raw:
The documentation has been updated to answer your questions:

1. That is correct, the camera will always follow the model by changing its orientation.
2. That is correct, the documentation has been updated to make it clearer to the user.
3. If static and relative are both true, the position of the camera is expressed in the model frame and therefore it should not be attached to the world. Are you sure that you did not set relative to false?
content.html:
The documentation has been updated to answer your questions:

  1. That is correct, the camera will always follow the model by changing its orientation.
  2. That is correct, the documentation has been updated to make it clearer to the user.
  3. If static and relative are both true, the position of the camera is expressed in the model frame and therefore it should not be attached to the world. Are you sure that you did not set relative to false?

content.raw: Can't this be integrated into `track_visual`?
content.html: Can't this be integrated into track_visual?

content.raw:
Looking at the gazebo pull request, it seems that this is using the tracked visual defined in the `track_visual` element, so I think it makes sense to introduce these extra parameters there.

Note that a "visual" in Gazebo is two levels below a "model". Models can be composed of many "links", and each link can have many "visuals".
content.html:
Looking at the gazebo pull request, it seems that this is using the tracked visual defined in the track_visual element, so I think it makes sense to introduce these extra parameters there.

Note that a "visual" in Gazebo is two levels below a "model". Models can be composed of many "links", and each link can have many "visuals".

content.raw:
As far as I know, <track_visual> is quite different from the follow mode:

* When <track_visual> is defined, it is mandatory to set a model name with the <name> element. The named model is then tracked at startup and it is not possible to escape this mode.
* The <track_visual> element also has two subelements, <min_dist> and <max_dist>, which are defined but never used.
* And, more importantly, with <track_visual>, the position of the camera is not oriented towards the tracked model, which makes it unusable with aircrafts (_inheritOrientation is set to false by gzclient). And, if there was an option to inherit orientation from the visual node, pitch and roll would also be affected which is what we make to sure to prevent with this pull request.

The follow mode in gazebo and <track_visual> seem to serve two different purposes, so I am not sure it is a good idea to merge them. The idea of <follow_model> was simply to allow the user to configure the follow mode in their SDF files or in the client at runtime. We do not find the <track_visual> element convenient because, once enabled, it cannot be turned off in gzclient, and the way the camera moves is not what we expect when tracking a flying object. It also feels more user-friendly to determine the position of the camera relatively to the tracked model or to the world in a new <xyz> element instead of relying on the pose of the camera itself which may be completely different at startup. It is also nice to be able to change the camera parameters in gzclient, to adapt the behaviour of the camera to whatever object we decide to track. It is for all those reasons that we chose to modify the follow mode instead of <track_visual>. We added a new element to make it apparent to the user that it does not have any effect on <track_visual>.

In case you decide to merge <follow_model> into <track_visual>, I think that the <name> element should at least become optional. It should also be possible to leave this mode with the escape key, and to reenter it like with the follow mode. The <min_dist> and <max_dist> elements could be removed altogether unless you plan to use them. And, new SDF elements should be added to control precisely the way the camera is supposed to move relatively to the model or to the world.
content.html:
As far as I know, <track_visual> is quite different from the follow mode:

  • When <track_visual> is defined, it is mandatory to set a model name with the <name> element. The named model is then tracked at startup and it is not possible to escape this mode.
  • The <track_visual> element also has two subelements, <min_dist> and <max_dist>, which are defined but never used.
  • And, more importantly, with <track_visual>, the position of the camera is not oriented towards the tracked model, which makes it unusable with aircrafts (_inheritOrientation is set to false by gzclient). And, if there was an option to inherit orientation from the visual node, pitch and roll would also be affected which is what we make to sure to prevent with this pull request.

The follow mode in gazebo and <track_visual> seem to serve two different purposes, so I am not sure it is a good idea to merge them. The idea of <follow_model> was simply to allow the user to configure the follow mode in their SDF files or in the client at runtime. We do not find the <track_visual> element convenient because, once enabled, it cannot be turned off in gzclient, and the way the camera moves is not what we expect when tracking a flying object. It also feels more user-friendly to determine the position of the camera relatively to the tracked model or to the world in a new <xyz> element instead of relying on the pose of the camera itself which may be completely different at startup. It is also nice to be able to change the camera parameters in gzclient, to adapt the behaviour of the camera to whatever object we decide to track. It is for all those reasons that we chose to modify the follow mode instead of <track_visual>. We added a new element to make it apparent to the user that it does not have any effect on <track_visual>.

In case you decide to merge <follow_model> into <track_visual>, I think that the <name> element should at least become optional. It should also be possible to leave this mode with the escape key, and to reenter it like with the follow mode. The <min_dist> and <max_dist> elements could be removed altogether unless you plan to use them. And, new SDF elements should be added to control precisely the way the camera is supposed to move relatively to the model or to the world.

content.raw:
I was looking for examples of `track_visual` being used and found none. Then I tried using it and as you mentioned, it didn't seem to be very useful.

It seems to me that this is old functionality which is not properly supported any more, maybe someone who has been around longer can comment on that. I traced it back to a commit from @nkoenig.

It feels to me that we could improve the functionality of `track_visual` with the features proposed in this pull request instead of adding another way to define a follow mode.

1. Merge it with follow mode and make it possible to leave the mode from the GUI.

1. Add more parameters to configure the movement, maybe get rid of existing parameters which are not being used.
content.html:
I was looking for examples of track_visual being used and found none. Then I tried using it and as you mentioned, it didn't seem to be very useful.

It seems to me that this is old functionality which is not properly supported any more, maybe someone who has been around longer can comment on that. I traced it back to a commit from @nkoenig.

It feels to me that we could improve the functionality of track_visual with the features proposed in this pull request instead of adding another way to define a follow mode.

  1. Merge it with follow mode and make it possible to leave the mode from the GUI.

  2. Add more parameters to configure the movement, maybe get rid of existing parameters which are not being used.

content.raw: What would be tracked if a name is not provided?

content.raw: Nothing would be tracked. I just want to make sure that the user can define his own set of parameters without having to track a visual right at the start. Then, whenever he decides to right-click-follow a model, the SDF parameters that he defined will be used instead of the defaults.
content.html: Nothing would be tracked. I just want to make sure that the user can define his own set of parameters without having to track a visual right at the start. Then, whenever he decides to right-click-follow a model, the SDF parameters that he defined will be used instead of the defaults.

content.html: Thanks for the clarification. Sounds good.

content.raw: `inherit_yaw` and `xyz` can't be used at the same time, right? Is this documented somewhere?
content.html: inherit_yaw and xyz can't be used at the same time, right? Is this documented somewhere?

content.raw:
Actually, they can be used simultaneously.

* `name` and `static` are never ignored.
* `min_dist` and `max_dist` are ignored when `static` is true.
* `relative` and `xyz` are ignored when `static` is false.
* `inherit_yaw` is ignored when `static` is false or when `relative` is false. In other words, it is only used if `static` and `relative` are both true.
content.html:
Actually, they can be used simultaneously.

  • name and static are never ignored.
  • min_dist and max_dist are ignored when static is true.
  • relative and xyz are ignored when static is false.
  • inherit_yaw is ignored when static is false or when relative is false. In other words, it is only used if static and relative are both true.

content.raw:
This list is very useful.

Let me see if I didn't get lost here. So when we set `static` and `relative` to true, this means we want the camera at a specific position (`xyz`) in model frame, and orientation is automatically adjusted to look at the model, right? 

But then if we choose `inherit_yaw` in this case, the camera would either "look at the same direction as the model is looking", which might not include the model in the view, or change the position (disrespect `xyz`) to  fulfil the `inherit_yaw` condition and stay behind the model. I tested a bit and it seems that the 2nd option is happening, but I might be misunderstanding something.
content.html:
This list is very useful.

Let me see if I didn't get lost here. So when we set static and relative to true, this means we want the camera at a specific position (xyz) in model frame, and orientation is automatically adjusted to look at the model, right?

But then if we choose inherit_yaw in this case, the camera would either "look at the same direction as the model is looking", which might not include the model in the view, or change the position (disrespect xyz) to fulfil the inherit_yaw condition and stay behind the model. I tested a bit and it seems that the 2nd option is happening, but I might be misunderstanding something.

content.raw: I think I misunderstood what `inherit_yaw` is supposed to mean... And now I'm more confused :]
content.html: I think I misunderstood what inherit_yaw is supposed to mean... And now I'm more confused :]

content.raw:
Yes, you are right about `static` and `relative` fields.
I made a video for you to see why `inherit_yaw` is useful: https://youtu.be/2xzC5AADzqg
When following an aircraft, we find it more convenient when the camera inherits the yaw rotation of the visual. In other cases, this behaviour may not be desired, so that is why it can be disabled by setting `inherit_yaw` to false. The pitch and roll of the visual are always ignored.
content.html: Yes, you are right about static and relative fields. I made a video for you to see why inherit_yaw is useful: https://youtu.be/2xzC5AADzqg When following an aircraft, we find it more convenient when the camera inherits the yaw rotation of the visual. In other cases, this behaviour may not be desired, so that is why it can be disabled by setting inherit_yaw to false. The pitch and roll of the visual are always ignored.

content.raw:
Ohhh I see, thanks for going through the trouble of making a video to clarify things! 

I see now what was confusing me so much! Even when it's set to `use_model_frame`, `xyz` is still *expressed* in the world frame, right? It's easier to draw than to explain with words:

![track_visual.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/ak8x4z/images/702126898-track_visual.png)

I was expecting something like `A`. So I think your implementation is `B`, correct? I think it's fine, it would be just nice to make it clear in the documentation that it's all expressed in the world frame.

And just to double check, there's no way to get to behaviour `A` using this set of parameters, right?
content.html:
Ohhh I see, thanks for going through the trouble of making a video to clarify things!

I see now what was confusing me so much! Even when it's set to use_model_frame, xyz is still expressed in the world frame, right? It's easier to draw than to explain with words:

I was expecting something like A. So I think your implementation is B, correct? I think it's fine, it would be just nice to make it clear in the documentation that it's all expressed in the world frame.

And just to double check, there's no way to get to behaviour A using this set of parameters, right?

content.raw:
Thank you very much for your drawings, they cleared things up. The implementation corresponds to figure `B`. My guess is that it should generally be more straightforward for the user to express the position of the camera in world frame rather than in model frame, and then set `inherit_yaw` to `true` whenever desired.

To get the behaviour of figure `B`, we could replace `inherit_yaw` by a more generic `inherit_rot` vector3. In that case, the behaviour of figure `A` could be obtained by setting `<inherit_rot>` to `true true true`.
content.html:
Thank you very much for your drawings, they cleared things up. The implementation corresponds to figure B. My guess is that it should generally be more straightforward for the user to express the position of the camera in world frame rather than in model frame, and then set inherit_yaw to true whenever desired.

To get the behaviour of figure B, we could replace inherit_yaw by a more generic inherit_rot vector3. In that case, the behaviour of figure A could be obtained by setting <inherit_rot> to true true true.

content.raw: Cool, I think it's ok the way it is, behaviour `A` might not be useful at all. Extra params could be added in the future ;)
content.html: Cool, I think it's ok the way it is, behaviour A might not be useful at all. Extra params could be added in the future ;)
